active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a debate format, argue whether trade secrets or patents provide better long-term IP protection in cybersecurity contexts. Use real-world breach examples (e.g., from institutedata.com or nist.gov references) to support your position, considering factors like enforcement, cost, and digital vulnerability.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator specializing in university-level cybersecurity education. Generate high-quality Anki-compatible flashcards for the topic 'Intellectual Property Protection' (Category: Cybersecurity, Domain: 008_Application Security > Web 008_Application Security; Entry: 012_Data Protection and Privacy > Sensitive Data Identification; Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 008_Application Security > Web 008_Application Security > 012_Data Protection and Privacy > Sensitive Data Identification > Intellectual Property Protection). Incorporate: - Research: IP as mind creations (inventions, works [institutedata.com]); Cybersecurity protection [nist.gov]; Threats (hacking, insiders, supply chain vulns: third-party risks); Protections (classification, encryption, DLP); Consequences (financial loss [conleyrose.com]). - Bloom's Objectives: [Insert the 6 objectives from above]. - Active Learning: Draw from discussion (trade secrets vs patents), peer teaching (IP types/threats), problem-solving (web app scenario). - Scaffolding: [Insert the 4 layers from above]; tag each card accordingly. Output 75 flashcards in JSON array: [{'type': 'mcq/definition/etc.', 'front': '...', 'back': '...', 'explanation': '... (link to objectives/layers/active inspo)', 'bloom_level': '...', 'scaffolding_layer': 1-4, 'references': '...'}]. Follow schema exactly: MCQs have 4 options on front. Distractors per protocol. Ensure active recall, no hints on front. Vary phrasing for spaced repetition. Cover completeness: full threats (supply chain: vendor compromises exposing IP), strategies (NIST integration).
